org.orgName: United States District Court, For the Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: MISS FRANKIE RUSSELL, 821 Campbell Ave.
called as a witness, being first sworn, testified as follows:
96 Q. You live in the same house, or rather the last witness lives in the same house you do? A. Yes
97 Q. Do you know Lewis Johnston? A. Yes
98 Q. How long have you known him? A. I have known him about six months.

99 Q. Will you tell us shortly what happened on Saturday, that would be the 4th of June and from then on as far as you personally know about it? A. Johnston came to our house between 4 and 5 in the morning and knocked on the door. I told him first we were in bed; he said it was important, that he wanted to see Mr. Tate. I opened the door and let him in and called Mr. Tate; and him and Mr Tate were talking and my- self. He had a bottle of gin with him and some fancy cigarettes and a bottle of cream, and he said that the reason he said it was important he thought we would not let him in. We drank there for awhile, and he asked Mr. Tate if he would go up-town to get him some underwear and shoes. Mr Tate said he would. He wanted Mr. Tate to go up-town with him. He said "what is the object of going up-town so early in the morning?" and he said "I have to see Garnett before Garnett goes to bed." The rest he knows. He came back to the house and he drank a considerable bit, and when I saw this money I asked him where this money came from.

100 Q. What money? A. Two fifty dollar bills. And he said he
got it from the American Government for work in the Phillipines He gave Mr Tate one fifty dollar bill to go up-town and buy him a shirt and buy some underwear - no some underwear and a pair of shoes. Later on in the afternoon Mr. Tate was going up-town after some beer and he gave him another one of those fifty dollar bills; and Mr Tate said "why you have change" and he said "Yes but I want this one changed as I am going over to the other side and it is more convenient to take it in smaller denominations."

101 Q. Now will you get it right down to the time when he began to make explanations about where he got that money? A. It was about Sunday afternoon he had a big package of cocaine and we allowed that he was full of cocaine and didn't know what he was talking about. On Sunday afternoon all of a sudden he straightened up. He would not drink any more and he acted as if he was worried, and I said to Mr Tate "maybe he has done something wrong; maybe he killed somebody for that money" And he talked about he had more money, he said he had lots of monye, when left our place he said he was going to leave town; and he told us that he had eighteen hundred dollars; told us that he made it off a man that was drunk in the Main Hotel bar. The man was asleep in the lavatory. He went to raise him and he felt the purse in his pocket, and said there were two fifty dollar bills, three ten dollar bills, and seventeen one hundred dollar bills that the man had in his pocket. On Monday I told him, I said "if you have done anything.....

102 Q. Monday? He was still in town on Monday? A. Yes this was early in the morning. I said "if you have done anything crooked for that, I don't want you to get ourseleves in wrong" He said "you talk as if you would be a snitch" I said "I don't call that snitching. I am protecting ourselves." about three o'clock in the morning we had a nice sleeping draught and woke up between four and five Monday afternoon.
103 Q. Given to who? A. Me and Mr Tate

104 Q. Just in what form was the sleeping draught given? A. He said he was going up-town and asked us if we would have anything before he went, and took a glass off the stand and filled the glass with whiskey out of his hip and gave T- ate a drink and me out of the same glass, and he said he wouldn't drink his without water; and he walked into the kitchen and that is the last I saw of Johnston.
104 Q. He didn't drink out of the glass? A. He took the same glass
105 Q. After you had drunk it? A. Yes
106 COURT: You don't know whether he drank it? A. I don't think he drank it.
107 Q. What happened to you? A. Both of us went to sleep in the same room and when we woke up it was between four and five in the afternoon.
108 Q. That is you had slept right from between three and four in the early morning till between four and five in the afternoon? About fourteen hours A. Yes
109 Q. Did you drink heavily yourself? A. No not very
110 Q. Had you been drinking much that night? A. Not that after noon.
111 Q. And Tate tells us he doesn't drink much himself? A. No he doesn't drink
112 Q. Now is that a photograph of Johnston, Lewis Johnston? A. Yes
113 Q. You recognise him by that, do? A. Yes
MR KENNEDY: This photograph has already been put in as Exhibit "A#
Your worship
